ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: It is a field trip, so I declined to answer the field trip question.

This is above and beyond one of the best learning experiences I've had at Yale. Mike is an excellent discussion leader, and he does a wonderful job of meeting individual students at their own level of understanding. The course shows in practice the type of forestry that we can't really see in New England. No one should graduate from the best forestry school in the US without visiting the timber basket of the US (the South). The cultural experience is also wonderful. I highly, highly recommend this course.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: It gives you a valuable chance to see on the ground forestry, which is very important for forestry students who have gone taken the courses but not really seeing different practices on the ground.

I thought that we went to a very diverse selection of forest management operations. I liked that we got to see both private organizations and government owned forest, and learning about the motivations that influence key decision making in both of those realms. All of our tour guides were excellent! They were extremely responsive to the students and were very knowledgeable! Mike and Rebecca did an excellent job organizing the itinerary. We were busy but not overwhelmingly so.
Great trip!

Field trips are as useful as the best of the courses for you to understand sectors or areas of the World. This was a fantastic experience for getting to know the South-East and how forestry takes place there.

Each day brings a new learning opportunity, from seeing plantation style forestry to wildlife habitats. There's just the right amount of down time to feel that you can absorb all you need and want to without feeling bored. And, you get to learn from experts in the field as well as your peers. All around a wonderful experience.
This course is so important for the forestry curriculum! It exposes us to the sector of forest resource management that dominates the markets and that we are unable to learn about from up here in NE.

The opportunity to meet and interact with a variety of different forestry practitioners across South Carolina is incredible. I came away from the course with a much better grasp of how pine ecosystems are managed, and how industrial forestry works.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I see no real room for improvement. Everything runs very smoothly, and I feel that as much learning as can be comfortable achieved is actually achieved. Maybe rent cars that have higher undercarriages? Beyond that, a huge job well done.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The lecturer of the course is the most articulate person when he is on the ground. He helps the student to ask the "stupid" questions to the guides, the foresters, and the managers from timber companies. He is great.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I heavily focused on forestry even I am a MEM student. I wish to bring some of the forestry practices back to Tibet, thus, this course perfectly fits into my overall program.
I had very little exposure to forestry beforehand so this was very eye-opening. I mostly took the course due to personal interest, and I got all of my questions answered that I had wanted.

As someone with interest in the international aspects of forestry, forest products, etc. this course was a must. I truly enjoyed it, learned a lot and I am so happy about it being offered. It was one of the highlights in the semester.
I'm from the South, and this course gave me a chance to learn more about the environment that I hope to on day work in.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: 1. I have never been to the southern part of the country, so I want to experience the culture that part of the US. 2. To see on the ground forestry.
I wanted to learn about private pine forest management operations

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, I did.
Yes, everyone was extremely knowledgable and I learned a lot, despite the trip only being a week.
Yes!
Yes, and then some!
Yes, absolutely.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Everyday, we did debriefings. It was very reflective and helpful to hear different perspectives on what we have seen on that day.

Group work is hugely advantageous--everyone gets to learn together. I loved whole-group discussions where everyone shared their thoughts on the day, or struggles with what we were learning about. This is one aspect that makes the course as successful as it is.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It is a MUST for forestry students, but even for MEMs it is a great learning experience.

This is an excellent course, and it's even better if you know what to look for. At times, Mike just let us explore a little bit in the forest stands, and it's helpful if you have a little bit of knowledge so you can distinguish interesting/concerning/cool things.
If you study forestry in the US you have to take this course if you are not very familiar already with forestry in the SE
Do it! Go with an open mind, take notes, and enjoy every moment.
This trip is an amazing opportunity to see a different side of forestry than you see in the rest of the program.
